For cancers where brain metastasis is a concern, such as mucosal melanoma or high-grade neuroendocrine carcinomas or adenocarcinomas , contrast-enhanced brain MRI should be additionally obtained .\\n If FDG-PET/CT is not performed , CT of the chest should be performed to assess for presence of pulmonary metastases as well as mediastinal lymph node involvement .\\n Non-contrast CT of the chest can be sufficient to screen for lung parenchymal metastases but is not adequate for assessment of mediastinal adenopathy . This is an appropriate lung cancer screening intervention for patients with a history of smoking .\\n Following primary definitive treatment (surgery, RT, or systemic therapy/RT) the role of annual CT screening for lung metastasis is controversial. While this approach does detect early metastasis , further study is needed to determine the extent of the positive effect and/or cost-effectiveness of this approach in specific subpopulations and timepoints post-treatment . For patients with a substantial smoking history or who are at high risk for lung metastases , annual chest CT can be considered .\\n If clinical concern for metastatic disease is confined to a specific anatomical area , the assessment of distant disease can be performed with directed CT or MRI examination .\\n FDG-PET/CT may complement or replace other imaging modalities when staging recurrent disease before any therapy for relapsed/refractory disease in order to explore distant disease or second primaries that may significantly impact choice of therapy .\\n--------------------------------------------------\\nPage Number: 93\\n\\nSection Name: PRINCIPLES OF IMAGING\\n====================\\nEntities:-\\nImaging, Diagnostic : The production of a visual representation of parts of the body, for the purpose of clinical analysis and medical intervention.\\nHead And Neck Neoplasms : Tumors or cancer of the head and neck region, including the nasal cavity, sinuses, lips, mouth, salivary glands, throat, or larynx.\\nTomography, X-Ray Computed : An imaging procedure that uses special x-ray equipment to create detailed pictures, or scans, of areas inside the body.\\nMagnetic Resonance Imaging : A noninvasive diagnostic technique that uses magnetic fields and radio waves to produce a detailed image of the body\\'s soft tissue and bones.\\nContrast Media : Substances used to enhance the contrast of structures or fluids within the body in medical imaging.\\n\\nRelationships:-\\n1. It includes a comprehensive history and physical examination (H&P), which should document tobacco and alcohol use, and provide counseling for smoking cessation. A biopsy of the primary site is required, and direct laryngoscopy under anesthesia is generally recommended. Imaging studies such as CT scans with contrast and possibly MRI are used to evaluate the larynx and neck. Additional evaluations may include chest CT, FDG-PET/CT, pulmonary function tests, dental evaluation, and nutrition, speech, and swallowing therapy. Multidisciplinary consultation is advised as clinically indicated.\\n\\nSection Name: Clinical Staging\\n====================\\nEntities:-\\nCancer : A group of diseases involving abnormal cell growth with the potential to invade or spread to other parts of the body.\\nCarcinoma In Situ : A lesion with cytological characteristics of cancer but which has not invaded the basement membrane.\\nBiopsy : A medical test involving the extraction of sample cells or tissues for examination.\\nLaryngectomy : A surgical procedure to remove the larynx.\\n\\nRelationships:-\\n1. It starts with carcinoma in situ, which is non-invasive, and progresses through stages T1-T4. Staging is based on H&P, biopsy, and imaging studies . For T1-T2 , larynx-preserving surgeries are considered , while more advanced stages like T3 or T4 may require total laryngectomy . Additional evaluations such as videostrobe, audiogram, and fertility counseling may be considered .\\n\\nSection Name: Treatment\\n====================\\nEntities:-\\nCarcinoma In Situ : A lesion with cytological characteristics of cancer but which has not invaded the basement membrane.\\nLaryngectomy : A surgical procedure to remove the larynx.\\nMetastasis : The transfer of a disease from one organ or part to another not directly connected with it.\\nClinical Trials As Topic : Works about research studies that evaluate the effectiveness and safety of medications or medical devices by monitoring their effects on large groups of people.\\n\\nRelationships:-\\n1. Carcinoma in situ may be treated with larynx-preserving surgery. T1-T2 stages may also be amenable to conservation surgery. T3 stages may require total laryngectomy, especially if nodal involvement is present. T4a disease and unresectable or metastatic cases require more complex interventions. prompt: edge - The edge which needs to be verified. explanation - Explanation of what the edge represents and its validity. causal_direction - Either Positive or Negative or Unknown. A positive influence direction indicates that both factors change in the same direction (e.g. an increase causes an increase effect). A negative influence direction indicates the opposite changes (e.g. an increase causes a decrease effect). causal_factor - Is necessary or sufficient condition for an effect to occur. Exposure is a term commonly used in epidemiology to denote any condition that is considered as a possible cause of disease. Exposure is considered necessary when it always precedes the effects (e.g. symptoms) and always presents when the effects occur. A sufficient cause is a causal factor whose presence or occurrence guarantees the occurrence of symptom. causal_distance - Either Distal or Proximal or Unknown. The distal factors lie towards the beginning of causal chain (i.e. indirect causal factors). The the proximal factors lie towards the end of the chain (i.e. cause directly or almost directly the effect). Causality Tags: for action, for cause, for condition and for effect. Cause (C): The reason or origin that leads to an effect. Causes often involve disease conditions, risk factors, or underlying mechanisms. Effect (E): The outcome or result of a cause. Effects usually represent clinical outcomes, complications, or results of a specific cause. Condition (CO): The circumstance or prerequisite required for an action or effect to occur. Conditions may include patient characteristics, clinical scenarios, or specific diagnostic criteria. Action (A): The recommended or described response or activity to address a cause or condition. For patients with multistation or lower neck nodal involvement or high-grade tumor histology , consider CT of the chest to assess for mediastinal lymph node metastases or FDG-PET/CT , which is associated with higher sensitivity for both nodal and distant metastases . For patients who are under consideration for a surgical primary approach , the higher sensitivity of FDG-PET/CT is warranted for tumors approaching the midline, to determine the surgical approach to the contralateral neck . Similarly, patients who are scheduled for a definitive RT approach may benefit from the higher sensitivity of FDG-PET/CT for identifying involved lymph nodes . Entity1: "FDG-PET/CT", Entity2: "Recurrent Disease", Relationship: "used for staging" Causalities:- Patients with locoregionally advanced cancer (e.g., T3–T4 primary or ≥N1 nodal staging) , FDG-PET/CT is preferred to evaluate for distant disease and thoracic metastases . For cancers where brain metastasis is a concern, such as mucosal melanoma or high-grade neuroendocrine carcinomas or adenocarcinomas , contrast-enhanced brain MRI should be additionally obtained . If FDG-PET/CT is not performed , CT of the chest should be performed to assess for presence of pulmonary metastases as well as mediastinal lymph node involvement . Non-contrast CT of the chest can be sufficient to screen for lung parenchymal metastases but is not adequate for assessment of mediastinal adenopathy . This is an appropriate lung cancer screening intervention for patients with a history of smoking . Following primary definitive treatment (surgery, RT, or systemic therapy/RT) the role of annual CT screening for lung metastasis is controversial. While this approach does detect early metastasis , further study is needed to determine the extent of the positive effect and/or cost-effectiveness of this approach in specific subpopulations and timepoints post-treatment . For patients with a substantial smoking history or who are at high risk for lung metastases , annual chest CT can be considered . If clinical concern for metastatic disease is confined to a specific anatomical area , the assessment of distant disease can be performed with directed CT or MRI examination . FDG-PET/CT may complement or replace other imaging modalities when staging recurrent disease before any therapy for relapsed/refractory disease in order to explore distant disease or second primaries that may significantly impact choice of therapy . -------------------------------------------------- Page Number: 93 Section Name: PRINCIPLES OF IMAGING ==================== Entities:- Imaging, Diagnostic : The production of a visual representation of parts of the body, for the purpose of clinical analysis and medical intervention. It includes a comprehensive history and physical examination (H&P), which should document tobacco and alcohol use, and provide counseling for smoking cessation. A biopsy of the primary site is required, and direct laryngoscopy under anesthesia is generally recommended. Imaging studies such as CT scans with contrast and possibly MRI are used to evaluate the larynx and neck. Additional evaluations may include chest CT, FDG-PET/CT, pulmonary function tests, dental evaluation, and nutrition, speech, and swallowing therapy. Multidisciplinary consultation is advised as clinically indicated. Additional evaluations such as videostrobe, audiogram, and fertility counseling may be considered . The emphasis on concurrent treatments, such as systemic therapy combined with radiation , reflects current best practices in oncology, where multimodal approaches are often necessary to achieve better outcomes. The inclusion of clinical trials indicates an emphasis on maintaining up-to-date practices and personalized treatment plans as part of patient management strategies. Entity1: "CT Scan", Entity2: "Neck Dissection", Relationship: "leads to if positive" Causalities:- After systemic therapy or RT , a clinical assessment should occur 4 to 8 weeks later . If there is a response , it is necessary to assess the extent of disease or distant metastases, preferably through a FDG-PET/CT scan at a minimum of 12 weeks post-treatment . If the FDG-PET/CT results are negative , the patient may continue with monitoring through observation . In cases where the results are equivocal , observation or repeat FDG-PET/CT within 3 to 6 months is prescribed . In cases where the FDG-PET/CT results are strongly positive , further imaging via CT scan with contrast of the primary site and neck, or MRI with and without contrast, becomes necessary . If these imaging results confirm positive findings , neck dissection may be considered, depending on the evidence of residual or persistent disease . If the imaging findings are negative , the patient might continue in observation . prompt: edge - The edge which needs to be verified. explanation - Explanation of what the edge represents and its validity. causal_direction - Either Positive or Negative or Unknown. A positive influence direction indicates that both factors change in the same direction (e.g. an increase causes an increase effect). A negative influence direction indicates the opposite changes (e.g. an increase causes a decrease effect). causal_factor - Is necessary or sufficient condition for an effect to occur. Exposure is a term commonly used in epidemiology to denote any condition that is considered as a possible cause of disease. Exposure is considered necessary when it always precedes the effects (e.g. symptoms) and always presents when the effects occur. A sufficient cause is a causal factor whose presence or occurrence guarantees the occurrence of symptom. causal_distance - Either Distal or Proximal or Unknown. The distal factors lie towards the beginning of causal chain (i.e. indirect causal factors). The the proximal factors lie towards the end of the chain (i.e. cause directly or almost directly the effect). Causality Tags: for action, for cause, for condition and for effect. Cause (C): The reason or origin that leads to an effect. Causes often involve disease conditions, risk factors, or underlying mechanisms. Effect (E): The outcome or result of a cause. Effects usually represent clinical outcomes, complications, or results of a specific cause. Condition (CO): The circumstance or prerequisite required for an action or effect to occur. Conditions may include patient characteristics, clinical scenarios, or specific diagnostic criteria. Action (A): The recommended or described response or activity to address a cause or condition. Entity1: "glottic larynx cancer", Entity2: "multidisciplinary consultation", Relationship: "advised as clinically indicated" Causalities:- The workup section outlines the initial steps for diagnosing glottic larynx cancer. It includes a comprehensive history and physical examination (H&P), which should document tobacco and alcohol use, and provide counseling for smoking cessation. A biopsy of the primary site is required, and direct laryngoscopy under anesthesia is generally recommended. Imaging studies such as CT scans with contrast and possibly MRI are used to evaluate the larynx and neck. Additional evaluations may include chest CT, FDG-PET/CT, pulmonary function tests, dental evaluation, and nutrition, speech, and swallowing therapy. Multidisciplinary consultation is advised as clinically indicated. Section Name: Clinical Staging ==================== Entities:- Cancer : A group of diseases involving abnormal cell growth with the potential to invade or spread to other parts of the body. Carcinoma In Situ : A lesion with cytological characteristics of cancer but which has not invaded the basement membrane. Biopsy : A medical test involving the extraction of sample cells or tissues for examination. Laryngectomy : A surgical procedure to remove the larynx. Relationships:- 1. Entity1: "Total laryngectomy", Entity2: "Stages T3-T4", Relationship: "required for" Causalities:- Clinical staging involves categorizing the cancer based on its aggressiveness . It starts with carcinoma in situ, which is non-invasive, and progresses through stages T1-T4. Staging is based on H&P, biopsy, and imaging studies . For T1-T2 , larynx-preserving surgeries are considered , while more advanced stages like T3 or T4 may require total laryngectomy . Additional evaluations such as videostrobe, audiogram, and fertility counseling may be considered . Each step is meticulously organized to ensure that important factors are considered, such as the presence of adverse pathological features , which strongly influence treatment decisions . The emphasis on concurrent treatments, such as systemic therapy combined with radiation , reflects current best practices in oncology, where multimodal approaches are often necessary to achieve better outcomes. The inclusion of clinical trials indicates an emphasis on maintaining up-to-date practices and personalized treatment plans as part of patient management strategies. Furthermore, the chart's organization into treatment and follow-up segments allows for a straightforward interpretation, guiding oncologists through complex decisions in a logical manner. This can improve consistency in care and enhance patient safety through meticulous monitoring and responses to treatment efficacy or disease progression . In summary, this flowchart serves as an essential resource for oncologists, facilitating a better understanding of treatment protocols for glottic larynx cancer while promoting a patient-centered approach to oncological care . For patients with multistation or lower neck nodal involvement or high-grade tumor histology , consider CT of the chest to assess for mediastinal lymph node metastases or FDG-PET/CT , which is associated with higher sensitivity for both nodal and distant metastases . For patients who are under consideration for a surgical primary approach , the higher sensitivity of FDG-PET/CT is warranted for tumors approaching the midline, to determine the surgical approach to the contralateral neck . Similarly, patients who are scheduled for a definitive RT approach may benefit from the higher sensitivity of FDG-PET/CT for identifying involved lymph nodes . Entity1: "FDG-PET/CT", Entity2: "Recurrent Disease", Relationship: "used for staging" Causalities:- Patients with locoregionally advanced cancer (e.g., T3–T4 primary or ≥N1 nodal staging) , FDG-PET/CT is preferred to evaluate for distant disease and thoracic metastases . For cancers where brain metastasis is a concern, such as mucosal melanoma or high-grade neuroendocrine carcinomas or adenocarcinomas , contrast-enhanced brain MRI should be additionally obtained . If FDG-PET/CT is not performed , CT of the chest should be performed to assess for presence of pulmonary metastases as well as mediastinal lymph node involvement . Non-contrast CT of the chest can be sufficient to screen for lung parenchymal metastases but is not adequate for assessment of mediastinal adenopathy . This is an appropriate lung cancer screening intervention for patients with a history of smoking . Following primary definitive treatment (surgery, RT, or systemic therapy/RT) the role of annual CT screening for lung metastasis is controversial. While this approach does detect early metastasis , further study is needed to determine the extent of the positive effect and/or cost-effectiveness of this approach in specific subpopulations and timepoints post-treatment . For patients with a substantial smoking history or who are at high risk for lung metastases , annual chest CT can be considered . If clinical concern for metastatic disease is confined to a specific anatomical area , the assessment of distant disease can be performed with directed CT or MRI examination . FDG-PET/CT may complement or replace other imaging modalities when staging recurrent disease before any therapy for relapsed/refractory disease in order to explore distant disease or second primaries that may significantly impact choice of therapy . -------------------------------------------------- Page Number: 93 Section Name: PRINCIPLES OF IMAGING ==================== Entities:- Imaging, Diagnostic : The production of a visual representation of parts of the body, for the purpose of clinical analysis and medical intervention. prompt: edge - The edge which needs to be verified. explanation - Explanation of what the edge represents and its validity. causal_direction - Either Positive or Negative or Unknown. A positive influence direction indicates that both factors change in the same direction (e.g. an increase causes an increase effect). A negative influence direction indicates the opposite changes (e.g. an increase causes a decrease effect). causal_factor - Is necessary or sufficient condition for an effect to occur. Exposure is a term commonly used in epidemiology to denote any condition that is considered as a possible cause of disease. Exposure is considered necessary when it always precedes the effects (e.g. symptoms) and always presents when the effects occur. A sufficient cause is a causal factor whose presence or occurrence guarantees the occurrence of symptom. causal_distance - Either Distal or Proximal or Unknown. The distal factors lie towards the beginning of causal chain (i.e. indirect causal factors). The the proximal factors lie towards the end of the chain (i.e. cause directly or almost directly the effect). Causality Tags: for action, for cause, for condition and for effect. Cause (C): The reason or origin that leads to an effect. Causes often involve disease conditions, risk factors, or underlying mechanisms. Effect (E): The outcome or result of a cause. Effects usually represent clinical outcomes, complications, or results of a specific cause. Condition (CO): The circumstance or prerequisite required for an action or effect to occur. Conditions may include patient characteristics, clinical scenarios, or specific diagnostic criteria. Action (A): The recommended or described response or activity to address a cause or condition. If there is a response , it is necessary to assess the extent of disease or distant metastases, preferably through a FDG-PET/CT scan at a minimum of 12 weeks post-treatment . If the FDG-PET/CT results are negative , the patient may continue with monitoring through observation . In cases where the results are equivocal , observation or repeat FDG-PET/CT within 3 to 6 months is prescribed . In cases where the FDG-PET/CT results are strongly positive , further imaging via CT scan with contrast of the primary site and neck, or MRI with and without contrast, becomes necessary . If these imaging results confirm positive findings , neck dissection may be considered, depending on the evidence of residual or persistent disease . If the imaging findings are negative , the patient might continue in observation . For cancers where brain metastasis is a concern, such as mucosal melanoma or high-grade neuroendocrine carcinomas or adenocarcinomas , contrast-enhanced brain MRI should be additionally obtained . If FDG-PET/CT is not performed , CT of the chest should be performed to assess for presence of pulmonary metastases as well as mediastinal lymph node involvement . Non-contrast CT of the chest can be sufficient to screen for lung parenchymal metastases but is not adequate for assessment of mediastinal adenopathy . This is an appropriate lung cancer screening intervention for patients with a history of smoking . Following primary definitive treatment (surgery, RT, or systemic therapy/RT) the role of annual CT screening for lung metastasis is controversial. While this approach does detect early metastasis , further study is needed to determine the extent of the positive effect and/or cost-effectiveness of this approach in specific subpopulations and timepoints post-treatment . For patients with a substantial smoking history or who are at high risk for lung metastases , annual chest CT can be considered . If clinical concern for metastatic disease is confined to a specific anatomical area , the assessment of distant disease can be performed with directed CT or MRI examination . FDG-PET/CT may complement or replace other imaging modalities when staging recurrent disease before any therapy for relapsed/refractory disease in order to explore distant disease or second primaries that may significantly impact choice of therapy . -------------------------------------------------- Page Number: 55 Section Name: General Information ==================== Entities:- National Comprehensive Cancer Network : An alliance of 32 cancer centers in the United States, dedicated to improving the quality, effectiveness, and efficiency of cancer care. Section Name: PET/CT and Biopsy ==================== Entities:- Positron Emission Tomography Computed Tomography : A medical imaging technique that combines PET and CT capabilities to provide detailed images of the body. Examination Under Anesthesia : A procedure where a patient is examined while under anesthesia to allow for a more thorough examination. Biopsy : A medical test involving the extraction of sample cells or tissues for examination to determine the presence or extent of a disease. Tonsillectomy : A surgical procedure to remove the tonsils, often performed to treat recurrent tonsillitis or sleep apnea. Fine Needle Aspiration : A type of biopsy procedure that uses a thin, hollow needle to extract cells from a lump or mass for examination. Ultrasound : A medical imaging technique that uses high-frequency sound waves to visualize internal organs and structures. Computed Tomography : A diagnostic imaging procedure that uses a combination of X-rays and computer technology to produce cross-sectional images of the body. Relationships:- 1. Entity1: "Image-guided needle biopsy", Entity2: "cystic neck nodes", Relationship: "recommended for initial diagnosis of" Causalities:- If imaging does not reveal an obvious primary cancer , a PET/CT should be ordered before EUA, biopsies, and tonsillectomy . This helps identify potential primary sites before any interventions take place. Additionally, Fine Needle Aspiration (FNA) biopsy of metastatic nodes may provide pathologically informative results . For initial diagnosis in cystic neck nodes , image-guided needle biopsy (ultrasound or CT) may yield better results than FNA by palpation alone . Section Name: Postoperative Imaging Advice ==================== Entities:- Panoramic Radiography : A type of dental x-ray that provides a wide view of the upper and lower jaws, teeth, temporomandibular joints, and sinuses. prompt: edge - The edge which needs to be verified. explanation - Explanation of what the edge represents and its validity. causal_direction - Either Positive or Negative or Unknown. A positive influence direction indicates that both factors change in the same direction (e.g. an increase causes an increase effect). A negative influence direction indicates the opposite changes (e.g. an increase causes a decrease effect). causal_factor - Is necessary or sufficient condition for an effect to occur. Exposure is a term commonly used in epidemiology to denote any condition that is considered as a possible cause of disease. Exposure is considered necessary when it always precedes the effects (e.g. symptoms) and always presents when the effects occur. A sufficient cause is a causal factor whose presence or occurrence guarantees the occurrence of symptom. causal_distance - Either Distal or Proximal or Unknown. The distal factors lie towards the beginning of causal chain (i.e. indirect causal factors). The the proximal factors lie towards the end of the chain (i.e. cause directly or almost directly the effect). Causality Tags: for action, for cause, for condition and for effect. Cause (C): The reason or origin that leads to an effect. Causes often involve disease conditions, risk factors, or underlying mechanisms. Effect (E): The outcome or result of a cause. Effects usually represent clinical outcomes, complications, or results of a specific cause. Condition (CO): The circumstance or prerequisite required for an action or effect to occur. Conditions may include patient characteristics, clinical scenarios, or specific diagnostic criteria. Action (A): The recommended or described response or activity to address a cause or condition. Actions typically involve clinical interventions, diagnostic procedures, or treatment recommendations. `NODE1`: id: Presence_of_Metastasis_in_Lymph_Nodes_5 label: Metastasis in Nearby Lymph Nodes description: This node represents the clinical situation regarding whether metastasis is present in the nearby lymph nodes of a patient. These categories are pivotal in determining the next steps. CR indicates full resolution of the disease at the primary site , leading to the consideration of definitive radiation therapy or the likelihood of surgery . Conversely, PR suggests that the disease has improved but not completely resolved , which directs the pathway towards either systemic therapy or continued radiation therapy , with further evaluation necessary . Entity1: "CT Scan", Entity2: "Neck Dissection", Relationship: "leads to if positive" Causalities:- After systemic therapy or RT , a clinical assessment should occur 4 to 8 weeks later . If there is a response , it is necessary to assess the extent of disease or distant metastases, preferably through a FDG-PET/CT scan at a minimum of 12 weeks post-treatment . If the FDG-PET/CT results are negative , the patient may continue with monitoring through observation . In cases where the results are equivocal , observation or repeat FDG-PET/CT within 3 to 6 months is prescribed . In cases where the FDG-PET/CT results are strongly positive , further imaging via CT scan with contrast of the primary site and neck, or MRI with and without contrast, becomes necessary . If these imaging results confirm positive findings , neck dissection may be considered, depending on the evidence of residual or persistent disease . If the imaging findings are negative , the patient might continue in observation . Conversely, if it is deemed resectable , a resection of the primary and/or neck dissection may occur , contingent upon the disease status . It includes a comprehensive history and physical examination (H&P), which should document tobacco and alcohol use, and provide counseling for smoking cessation. A biopsy of the primary site is required, and direct laryngoscopy under anesthesia is generally recommended. Imaging studies such as CT scans with contrast and possibly MRI are used to evaluate the larynx and neck. Additional evaluations may include chest CT, FDG-PET/CT, pulmonary function tests, dental evaluation, and nutrition, speech, and swallowing therapy. Multidisciplinary consultation is advised as clinically indicated. It starts with carcinoma in situ, which is non-invasive, and progresses through stages T1-T4. Staging is based on H&P, biopsy, and imaging studies . Additional evaluations such as videostrobe, audiogram, and fertility counseling may be considered . This group is highlighted as those who are most capable of handling intensive treatments and may benefit significantly from combination therapies . - **For PS 2 Patients:** The recommended approach varies slightly, with a continued emphasis on systemic therapies, palliative radiation therapy, or best supportive care . This indicates a level of compromise in treatment options, suggesting that while aggressive treatment is still possible, the focus might shift more towards quality of life . - **For PS 3 Patients:** The treatment options further narrow, still recommending systemic therapy or supportive care but highlighting palliative approaches, reflecting a recognition of the more advanced disease and potentially limited treatment efficacy . It includes a comprehensive history and physical examination (H&P), which should document tobacco and alcohol use, and provide counseling for smoking cessation. A biopsy of the primary site is required, and direct laryngoscopy under anesthesia is generally recommended. Imaging studies such as CT scans with contrast and possibly MRI are used to evaluate the larynx and neck. Additional evaluations may include chest CT, FDG-PET/CT, pulmonary function tests, dental evaluation, and nutrition, speech, and swallowing therapy. prompt: edge - The edge which needs to be verified. explanation - Explanation of what the edge represents and its validity. causal_direction - Either Positive or Negative or Unknown. A positive influence direction indicates that both factors change in the same direction (e.g. an increase causes an increase effect). A negative influence direction indicates the opposite changes (e.g. an increase causes a decrease effect). causal_factor - Is necessary or sufficient condition for an effect to occur. Exposure is a term commonly used in epidemiology to denote any condition that is considered as a possible cause of disease. Exposure is considered necessary when it always precedes the effects (e.g. symptoms) and always presents when the effects occur. A sufficient cause is a causal factor whose presence or occurrence guarantees the occurrence of symptom. causal_distance - Either Distal or Proximal or Unknown. The distal factors lie towards the beginning of causal chain (i.e. indirect causal factors). The the proximal factors lie towards the end of the chain (i.e. cause directly or almost directly the effect). Causality Tags: for action, for cause, for condition and for effect. Cause (C): The reason or origin that leads to an effect. Causes often involve disease conditions, risk factors, or underlying mechanisms. Effect (E): The outcome or result of a cause. Effects usually represent clinical outcomes, complications, or results of a specific cause. Condition (CO): The circumstance or prerequisite required for an action or effect to occur. Conditions may include patient characteristics, clinical scenarios, or specific diagnostic criteria. Action (A): The recommended or described response or activity to address a cause or condition. Actions typically involve clinical interventions, diagnostic procedures, or treatment recommendations. `NODE1`: id: Location_of_Involved_Lymph_Nodes_4 label: Position of Affected Lymph Nodes in Patient description: This node represents the location of lymph nodes that are involved or affected in a patient's condition. MRI is performed with and without contrast , unless contraindicated . Entity1: "glottic larynx cancer", Entity2: "multidisciplinary consultation", Relationship: "advised as clinically indicated" Causalities:- The workup section outlines the initial steps for diagnosing glottic larynx cancer. It includes a comprehensive history and physical examination (H&P), which should document tobacco and alcohol use, and provide counseling for smoking cessation. A biopsy of the primary site is required, and direct laryngoscopy under anesthesia is generally recommended. Imaging studies such as CT scans with contrast and possibly MRI are used to evaluate the larynx and neck. Additional evaluations may include chest CT, FDG-PET/CT, pulmonary function tests, dental evaluation, and nutrition, speech, and swallowing therapy. Multidisciplinary consultation is advised as clinically indicated. It starts with carcinoma in situ, which is non-invasive, and progresses through stages T1-T4. Staging is based on H&P, biopsy, and imaging studies . For T1-T2 , larynx-preserving surgeries are considered , while more advanced stages like T3 or T4 may require total laryngectomy . Additional evaluations such as videostrobe, audiogram, and fertility counseling may be considered . Carcinoma in situ may be treated with larynx-preserving surgery. T1-T2 stages may also be amenable to conservation surgery. T3 stages may require total laryngectomy, especially if nodal involvement is present. T4a disease and unresectable or metastatic cases require more complex interventions. The guidelines emphasize the importance of multidisciplinary consultations and consider clinical trials as the best management option. The emphasis on concurrent treatments, such as systemic therapy combined with radiation , reflects current best practices in oncology, where multimodal approaches are often necessary to achieve better outcomes. The inclusion of clinical trials indicates an emphasis on maintaining up-to-date practices and personalized treatment plans as part of patient management strategies. Furthermore, the chart's organization into treatment and follow-up segments allows for a straightforward interpretation, guiding oncologists through complex decisions in a logical manner. This can improve consistency in care and enhance patient safety through meticulous monitoring and responses to treatment efficacy or disease progression . This is an appropriate lung cancer screening intervention for patients with a history of smoking . Following primary definitive treatment (surgery, RT, or systemic therapy/RT) the role of annual CT screening for lung metastasis is controversial. While this approach does detect early metastasis , further study is needed to determine the extent of the positive effect and/or cost-effectiveness of this approach in specific subpopulations and timepoints post-treatment . These categories are pivotal in determining the next steps. CR indicates full resolution of the disease at the primary site , leading to the consideration of definitive radiation therapy or the likelihood of surgery . This group is highlighted as those who are most capable of handling intensive treatments and may benefit significantly from combination therapies . - **For PS 2 Patients:** The recommended approach varies slightly, with a continued emphasis on systemic therapies, palliative radiation therapy, or best supportive care . A positive influence direction indicates that both factors change in the same direction (e.g. an increase causes an increase effect). A negative influence direction indicates the opposite changes (e.g. an increase causes a decrease effect). causal_factor - Is necessary or sufficient condition for an effect to occur. Exposure is a term commonly used in epidemiology to denote any condition that is considered as a possible cause of disease. Exposure is considered necessary when it always precedes the effects (e.g. symptoms) and always presents when the effects occur. A sufficient cause is a causal factor whose presence or occurrence guarantees the occurrence of symptom. causal_distance - Either Distal or Proximal or Unknown. The distal factors lie towards the beginning of causal chain (i.e. indirect causal factors). The the proximal factors lie towards the end of the chain (i.e. cause directly or almost directly the effect). Causality Tags: for action, for cause, for condition and for effect. Cause (C): The reason or origin that leads to an effect. Causes often involve disease conditions, risk factors, or underlying mechanisms. Effect (E): The outcome or result of a cause. Effects usually represent clinical outcomes, complications, or results of a specific cause. Condition (CO): The circumstance or prerequisite required for an action or effect to occur. Conditions may include patient characteristics, clinical scenarios, or specific diagnostic criteria. Action (A): The recommended or described response or activity to address a cause or condition. These categories are pivotal in determining the next steps. CR indicates full resolution of the disease at the primary site , leading to the consideration of definitive radiation therapy or the likelihood of surgery . Conversely, PR suggests that the disease has improved but not completely resolved , which directs the pathway towards either systemic therapy or continued radiation therapy , with further evaluation necessary . This is an appropriate lung cancer screening intervention for patients with a history of smoking .\\n Following primary definitive treatment (surgery, RT, or systemic therapy/RT) the role of annual CT screening for lung metastasis is controversial. While this approach does detect early metastasis , further study is needed to determine the extent of the positive effect and/or cost-effectiveness of this approach in specific subpopulations and timepoints post-treatment . For patients with a substantial smoking history or who are at high risk for lung metastases , annual chest CT can be considered .\\n If clinical concern for metastatic disease is confined to a specific anatomical area , the assessment of distant disease can be performed with directed CT or MRI examination .\\n FDG-PET/CT may complement or replace other imaging modalities when staging recurrent disease before any therapy for relapsed/refractory disease in order to explore distant disease or second primaries that may significantly impact choice of therapy .\\n--------------------------------------------------\\nPage Number: 53\\n\\nSection Name: Introduction\\n====================\\nEntities:-\\nNational Comprehensive Cancer Network : The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) is an alliance of 30 cancer centers in the United States, dedicated to improving the quality, effectiveness, and efficiency of cancer care so that patients can live better lives.\\nLaryngeal Neoplasms : Tumors or cancer of the larynx, which may affect the supraglottic, glottic, or subglottic regions.\\nMalignant Neoplasm Of Supraglottis : A malignant tumor located in the supraglottic region of the larynx.\\n\\nRelationships:-\\n1. It includes a comprehensive history and physical examination (H&P), which should document tobacco and alcohol use, and provide counseling for smoking cessation. A biopsy of the primary site is required, and direct laryngoscopy under anesthesia is generally recommended. Imaging studies such as CT scans with contrast and possibly MRI are used to evaluate the larynx and neck. Additional evaluations may include chest CT, FDG-PET/CT, pulmonary function tests, dental evaluation, and nutrition, speech, and swallowing therapy. prompt: edge - The edge which needs to be verified. explanation - Explanation of what the edge represents and its validity. causal_direction - Either Positive or Negative or Unknown. A positive influence direction indicates that both factors change in the same direction (e.g. an increase causes an increase effect). A negative influence direction indicates the opposite changes (e.g. an increase causes a decrease effect). causal_factor - Is necessary or sufficient condition for an effect to occur. Exposure is a term commonly used in epidemiology to denote any condition that is considered as a possible cause of disease. Exposure is considered necessary when it always precedes the effects (e.g. symptoms) and always presents when the effects occur. A sufficient cause is a causal factor whose presence or occurrence guarantees the occurrence of symptom. causal_distance - Either Distal or Proximal or Unknown. The distal factors lie towards the beginning of causal chain (i.e. indirect causal factors). The the proximal factors lie towards the end of the chain (i.e. cause directly or almost directly the effect). Causality Tags: for action, for cause, for condition and for effect. Cause (C): The reason or origin that leads to an effect. Causes often involve disease conditions, risk factors, or underlying mechanisms. Effect (E): The outcome or result of a cause. Effects usually represent clinical outcomes, complications, or results of a specific cause. Condition (CO): The circumstance or prerequisite required for an action or effect to occur. Conditions may include patient characteristics, clinical scenarios, or specific diagnostic criteria. Action (A): The recommended or described response or activity to address a cause or condition. Actions typically involve clinical interventions, diagnostic procedures, or treatment recommendations. `NODE1`: id: Location_of_Involved_Lymph_Nodes_4 label: Position of Affected Lymph Nodes in Patient description: This node represents the location of lymph nodes that are involved or affected in a patient's condition. Understanding whether the lymph nodes are ipsilateral, bilateral, or contralateral is crucial for determining the extent of disease spread and planning appropriate treatment strategies. type: Patient Situation observability: Unobserved states: [{'state_name': 'ipsilateral', 'state_description': 'The involved lymph nodes are on the same side of the body as the primary tumor or reference point. This can indicate localized spread of disease.'}, {'state_name': 'bilateral', 'state_description': 'The involved lymph nodes are on both sides of the body. This may suggest a more extensive spread of disease and can impact treatment decisions.'}, {'state_name': 'contralateral', 'state_description': 'The involved lymph nodes are on the opposite side of the body from the primary tumor or reference point. This can indicate metastatic spread and may affect staging and treatment planning.'}] `NODE2`: id: Magnetic_Resonance_Imaging_MRI_14 label: Magnetic Resonance Imaging description: This node represents the results of an MRI examination focused on detecting lymph node metastasis. It indicates whether metastasis is present in lymph nodes and specifies the pattern of metastasis (bilateral, ipsilateral, or contralateral) as observed through MRI. type: Examination Result observability: Observed states: [{'state_name': 'bilateral_lymph_node_metastasis', 'state_description': 'Metastasis is present in lymph nodes on both sides of the body as detected by MRI.'}, {'state_name': 'ipsilateral_lymph_node_metastasis', 'state_description': 'Metastasis is present in lymph nodes on the same side as the primary tumor as detected by MRI.'}, {'state_name': 'contralateral_lymph_node_metastasis', 'state_description': 'Metastasis is present in lymph nodes on the opposite side of the primary tumor as detected by MRI.'}] `EDGE1`: {'edges_ids': ['Location_of_Involved_Lymph_Nodes_4', 'Magnetic_Resonance_Imaging_MRI_14'], 'edge': '(Location_of_Involved_Lymph_Nodes_4) causes (Magnetic_Resonance_Imaging_MRI_14)', 'explanation': ['The edge suggests that the location of involved lymph nodes causes the MRI results, which is not valid.', 'The MRI results are an observation of the lymph node involvement, not caused by it.', 'The MRI is used to detect the presence and pattern of lymph node metastasis, not influenced by the lymph node location.'], 'causal_direction': 'Unknown', 'causal_factor': {'necessary': False, 'sufficient': False}, 'causal_distance': 'Unknown'} `EDGE2`: {'edges_ids': ['Magnetic_Resonance_Imaging_MRI_14', 'Location_of_Involved_Lymph_Nodes_4'], 'edge': '(Magnetic_Resonance_Imaging_MRI_14) causes (Location_of_Involved_Lymph_Nodes_4)', 'explanation': ['The edge represents the idea that the results of an MRI examination (Magnetic_Resonance_Imaging_MRI_14) could cause or determine the location of involved lymph nodes (Location_of_Involved_Lymph_Nodes_4).', 'However, the MRI results are an observation of the lymph nodes` state, not a cause of their state. For patients with multistation or lower neck nodal involvement or high-grade tumor histology , consider CT of the chest to assess for mediastinal lymph node metastases or FDG-PET/CT , which is associated with higher sensitivity for both nodal and distant metastases . For patients who are under consideration for a surgical primary approach , the higher sensitivity of FDG-PET/CT is warranted for tumors approaching the midline, to determine the surgical approach to the contralateral neck . Similarly, patients who are scheduled for a definitive RT approach may benefit from the higher sensitivity of FDG-PET/CT for identifying involved lymph nodes . Entity1: "FDG-PET/CT", Entity2: "Recurrent Disease", Relationship: "used for staging" Causalities:- Patients with locoregionally advanced cancer (e.g., T3–T4 primary or ≥N1 nodal staging) , FDG-PET/CT is preferred to evaluate for distant disease and thoracic metastases . For cancers where brain metastasis is a concern, such as mucosal melanoma or high-grade neuroendocrine carcinomas or adenocarcinomas , contrast-enhanced brain MRI should be additionally obtained . If FDG-PET/CT is not performed , CT of the chest should be performed to assess for presence of pulmonary metastases as well as mediastinal lymph node involvement . Non-contrast CT of the chest can be sufficient to screen for lung parenchymal metastases but is not adequate for assessment of mediastinal adenopathy . This is an appropriate lung cancer screening intervention for patients with a history of smoking . Following primary definitive treatment (surgery, RT, or systemic therapy/RT) the role of annual CT screening for lung metastasis is controversial. While this approach does detect early metastasis , further study is needed to determine the extent of the positive effect and/or cost-effectiveness of this approach in specific subpopulations and timepoints post-treatment . For patients with a substantial smoking history or who are at high risk for lung metastases , annual chest CT can be considered . If clinical concern for metastatic disease is confined to a specific anatomical area , the assessment of distant disease can be performed with directed CT or MRI examination . FDG-PET/CT may complement or replace other imaging modalities when staging recurrent disease before any therapy for relapsed/refractory disease in order to explore distant disease or second primaries that may significantly impact choice of therapy . -------------------------------------------------- Page Number: 53 Section Name: Introduction ==================== Entities:- National Comprehensive Cancer Network : The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) is an alliance of 30 cancer centers in the United States, dedicated to improving the quality, effectiveness, and efficiency of cancer care so that patients can live better lives. This is essential for deciding on appropriate treatment options. 2. **Treatment of Primary and Neck**: The flowchart details multiple treatment strategies, including: - **Concurrent systemic therapy/RT**: This suggests a combination approach for patients eligible for such treatment. - **Definitive Radiation Therapy (RT)**: Recommended for low-volume diseases or patients who cannot tolerate systemic therapy. - **Surgical Options**: It highlights options such as endoscopic or open partial laryngectomy and neck dissection, which are contingent on clinical evaluations. 3. **Evaluation and Follow-Up**: After initial treatment approaches, the chart directs clinicians to perform a "Post Systemic Therapy/RT or RT Neck Evaluation". This step assesses whether there are adverse pathologic features, guiding subsequent treatment decisions. 4. **Adverse and No Adverse Features**: The decision pathway diverges based on findings: - Patients with **adverse pathologic features** may have additional diagnostic imaging (CT or MRI) and may require further systemic treatment. - Patients with **no adverse features** may be directed towards considerations for radiation therapy. 5. **Adjuvant Treatment and Recurrence**: The chart also addresses management of any recurrent or persistent disease, emphasizing the importance of regular follow-up assessments. Various options for adjuvant treatment are mentioned, focusing on tailored approaches towards ongoing management of the disease. 6. **Clinical Trials**: The flowchart encourages participation in clinical trials, indicating a commitment to exploring new treatments and improving patient outcomes. It includes a comprehensive history and physical examination (H&P), which should document tobacco and alcohol use, and provide counseling for smoking cessation. A biopsy of the primary site is required, and direct laryngoscopy under anesthesia is generally recommended. Imaging studies such as CT scans with contrast and possibly MRI are used to evaluate the larynx and neck. Additional evaluations may include chest CT, FDG-PET/CT, pulmonary function tests, dental evaluation, and nutrition, speech, and swallowing therapy. Multidisciplinary consultation is advised as clinically indicated. It starts with carcinoma in situ, which is non-invasive, and progresses through stages T1-T4. Staging is based on H&P, biopsy, and imaging studies . For T1-T2 , larynx-preserving surgeries are considered , while more advanced stages like T3 or T4 may require total laryngectomy . Additional evaluations such as videostrobe, audiogram, and fertility counseling may be considered . Carcinoma in situ may be treated with larynx-preserving surgery. T1-T2 stages may also be amenable to conservation surgery. T3 stages may require total laryngectomy, especially if nodal involvement is present. T4a disease and unresectable or metastatic cases require more complex interventions. The guidelines emphasize the importance of multidisciplinary consultations and consider clinical trials as the best management option. Entity1: \"Imaging Modalities\", Entity2: \"Surveillance\", Relationship: \"used for\"\\n\\nCausalities:-\\n The majority of recurrences after treatment of head and neck cancer occur in the first 2 years . Surveillance can be challenging because of altered anatomy and/or fibrosis from surgery, radiation, and/or chemotherapy . There are no consensus guidelines on the frequency and modality of routine post-treatment imaging in the asymptomatic patient . Practice varies widely across institutions .\\n\\n US, CT, MRI, and PET/CT all have unique advantages and disadvantages when used as surveillance imaging . There is evidence that FDG-PET/CT may be the most sensitive of these modalities . A 12-month PET has been shown to reveal recurrent or second primary cancers in approximately 10% of treated patients ; a 24-month FDG-PET/CT imaging revealed these findings in approximately 5% of treated cases . Most cases of asymptomatic FDG-PET/CT lesion localization occur at distant sites . Whether earlier detection leads to improved disease-specific survival is not established .\\n\\n Standardized multi-institutional imaging-based trials are needed to clearly elucidate the value of routine imaging in the clinically asymptomatic patient . There may be little proven benefit in further imaging if the initial 3-month FDG-PET/CT scan was negative . Ho et al reported no significant difference in 3-year disease-free survival in patients undergoing imaging surveillance versus those only receiving clinical surveillance (41% vs. 46%, P = .91) in this setting .\\n\\n If an FDG-PET/CT at 3 months post-treatment is negative , there are no data to support substantial benefit for further routine imaging in an asymptomatic patient with negative exam . In the absence of multi-institutional prospective data, a tailored approach to surveillance with attention to tumor type, stage, prognostic factors, symptomatology, and physical exam changes or restrictions is appropriate .\\n\\n US of the neck is a well-established tool for nodal surveillance . US is generally widely available, safe, fast, inexpensive, and an accurate modality for examination of the neck for any suspicious nodal disease .\\n\\n Additional post-treatment imaging is indicated for worrisome or equivocal signs/symptoms .\\n\\n Routine annual imaging (repeat use of pretreatment imaging modality) may be indicated to visualize areas inaccessible to routine clinical examination (deep-seated anatomic locations or areas obscured by extensive treatment change) .\\n\\nSection Name: Principles of Imaging\\n====================\\nEntities:-\\nHead And Neck Neoplasms : Tumors or cancer of the head and neck region, including the nasal cavity, sinuses, lips, mouth, salivary glands, throat, or larynx.\\nHead And Neck Cancer : A group of cancers that originate in the head and neck region.\\nPositron-Emission Tomography : An imaging technique that uses radioactive substances to visualize and measure changes in metabolic processes.\\nPositron Emission Tomography : A type of nuclear medicine imaging that uses small amounts of radioactive materials to diagnose or treat a variety of diseases.\\nTomography, X-Ray Computed : A method of body imaging in which a thin X-ray beam rotates around the patient, producing signals that are processed by the computer to generate cross-sectional images.\\nComputed Tomography : A diagnostic imaging procedure that uses a combination of X-rays and computer technology to produce cross-sectional images.\\nNeck : The part of the body on many vertebrates that separates the head from the torso or trunk.\\n\\nRelationships:-\\n1. Entity1: \"Dental Radiography\", Entity2: \"Dentition\", Relationship: \"used for evaluation\"\\n\\nCausalities:-\\n Appropriate selection and utilization of imaging studies is crucial for proper care of patients with head and neck cancers .\\n Initial imaging of the primary site is performed with CT and/or MRI .\\n in patients with symptoms involving the cranial nerves or tumors encroaching on the skull base MRI is generally preferred over CT .\\n for evaluation of bony erosion or cartilage invasion that may occur with some head and neck tumors (e.g., laryngeal cancer) CT is complementary to MRI .\\n in patients with head and neck cancers involving the bone MRI is needed to evaluate the extent of bone marrow invasion .\\n in patients with head and neck cancers involving the bone CT is preferred to evaluate cortical bone erosion or periosteal invasion .\\n for cancers originating in the base of the tongue MRI can often delineate the boundary between gross tumor and normal muscle more effectively than CT .\\n for differentiating tumor extent from obstructed sinuses or secretions and to evaluate intracranial/dural involvement MRI is also preferable to CT .\\n depending on the primary site Evaluation of lymph node metastases can be done with either CT or MRI .\\n There is evidence to support the superiority of FDG-PET/CT for detecting locoregional nodal and distant metastases in patients with head and neck cancers .\\n in patients with clinically node-negative SCCHN the positive predictive value (PPV) and negative predictive value (NPV) of FDG-PET/CT for detection of cervical lymph node involvement was 0.62 (95% CI, 0.55\u20130.69) and 0.83 (95% CI, 0.79\u20130.86), respectively .\\n in patients with cN0 disease 125/144 (87%) negative PET scans were pathologically negative at neck dissection .\\n Findings from PET/CT changed the surgical plan in 22% of patients .\\n for detection of cervical lymph node metastases by FDG-PET/CT a prospective single-center study from Germany (N = 150) showed an NPV of 93.3% (95% CI, 88.2%\u201398.5%) .\\n if there is concern about metastasis to a specific anatomic area directed CT or MRI may also be performed .\\n Head and neck cancers rarely metastasize to the brain by a hematogenous route ordering a full brain study as part of the initial imaging workup is not routine .\\n for patients who are The Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy Head and Neck (FACT-H&N) scale\\n\\n- The Performance Status Scale is a clinician-rated performance scale widely used for patients with head and neck cancers.\\n\\n- The Oral Mucositis Weekly Questionnaire HN (OMWQ-HN) is a validated patient-reported instrument that measures the symptoms of oral mucositis, including mouth and throat pain, and its impact on well-being and function.\\n\\n Use of the Patient-Reported Outcomes version of the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events is encouraged to facilitate evaluation of symptomatic toxicity in patients enrolled in cancer clinical trials .\\n'}"
prompt: edge - The edge which needs to be verified. explanation - Explanation of what the edge represents and its validity. causal_direction - Either Positive or Negative or Unknown. A positive influence direction indicates that both factors change in the same direction (e.g. an increase causes an increase effect). A negative influence direction indicates the opposite changes (e.g. an increase causes a decrease effect). causal_factor - Is necessary or sufficient condition for an effect to occur. Exposure is a term commonly used in epidemiology to denote any condition that is considered as a possible cause of disease. Exposure is considered necessary when it always precedes the effects (e.g. symptoms) and always presents when the effects occur. A sufficient cause is a causal factor whose presence or occurrence guarantees the occurrence of symptom. causal_distance - Either Distal or Proximal or Unknown. The distal factors lie towards the beginning of causal chain (i.e. indirect causal factors). The the proximal factors lie towards the end of the chain (i.e. cause directly or almost directly the effect). Causality Tags: for action, for cause, for condition and for effect. Cause (C): The reason or origin that leads to an effect. Causes often involve disease conditions, risk factors, or underlying mechanisms. Effect (E): The outcome or result of a cause. Effects usually represent clinical outcomes, complications, or results of a specific cause. Condition (CO): The circumstance or prerequisite required for an action or effect to occur. Conditions may include patient characteristics, clinical scenarios, or specific diagnostic criteria. Action (A): The recommended or described response or activity to address a cause or condition. Actions typically involve clinical interventions, diagnostic procedures, or treatment recommendations. `NODE1`: id: Location_of_Involved_Lymph_Nodes_4 label: Position of Affected Lymph Nodes in Patient description: This node represents the location of lymph nodes that are involved or affected in a patient's condition. primary tumor, suggesting localized spread.'}, {'state_name': 'contralateral_lymph_node_metastasis', 'state_description': 'The PET scan shows metastasis in lymph nodes on the opposite side of the body For patients with multistation or lower neck nodal involvement or high-grade tumor histology , consider CT of the chest to assess for mediastinal lymph node metastases or FDG-PET/CT , which is associated with higher sensitivity for both nodal and distant metastases . For patients who are under consideration for a surgical primary approach , the higher sensitivity of FDG-PET/CT is warranted for tumors approaching the midline, to determine the surgical approach to the contralateral neck . Similarly, patients who are scheduled for a definitive RT approach may benefit from the higher sensitivity of FDG-PET/CT for identifying involved lymph nodes . For cancers where brain metastasis is a concern, such as mucosal melanoma or high-grade neuroendocrine carcinomas or adenocarcinomas , contrast-enhanced brain MRI should be additionally obtained . If FDG-PET/CT is not performed , CT of the chest should be performed to assess for presence of pulmonary metastases as well as mediastinal lymph node involvement . Non-contrast CT of the chest can be sufficient to screen for lung parenchymal metastases but is not adequate for assessment of mediastinal adenopathy . This is an appropriate lung cancer screening intervention for patients with a history of smoking . Following primary definitive treatment (surgery, RT, or systemic therapy/RT) the role of annual CT screening for lung metastasis is controversial. While this approach does detect early metastasis , further study is needed to determine the extent of the positive effect and/or cost-effectiveness of this approach in specific subpopulations and timepoints post-treatment . For patients with a substantial smoking history or who are at high risk for lung metastases , annual chest CT can be considered . If clinical concern for metastatic disease is confined to a specific anatomical area , the assessment of distant disease can be performed with directed CT or MRI examination . FDG-PET/CT may complement or replace other imaging modalities when staging recurrent disease before any therapy for relapsed/refractory disease in order to explore distant disease or second primaries that may significantly impact choice of therapy . -------------------------------------------------- Page Number: 92 Section Name: NCCN Guidelines Overview ==================== Entities:- Head And Neck Neoplasms : Cancers that arise in the head or neck region, including the nasal cavity, sinuses, lips, mouth, salivary glands, throat, or larynx. If there is a response , it is necessary to assess the extent of disease or distant metastases, preferably through a FDG-PET/CT scan at a minimum of 12 weeks post-treatment . If the FDG-PET/CT results are negative , the patient may continue with monitoring through observation . In cases where the results are equivocal , observation or repeat FDG-PET/CT within 3 to 6 months is prescribed . In cases where the FDG-PET/CT results are strongly positive , further imaging via CT scan with contrast of the primary site and neck, or MRI with and without contrast, becomes necessary . If these imaging results confirm positive findings , neck dissection may be considered, depending on the evidence of residual or persistent disease . If the imaging findings are negative , the patient might continue in observation . Surveillance : The ongoing systematic collection, analysis, and interpretation of health data essential to the planning, implementation, and evaluation of public health practice. Locoregional Recurrence Of Tumor : The return of cancer in the original tumor location or nearby lymph nodes after treatment. Asymptomatic : A condition or a person showing no symptoms of disease. Magnetic Resonance Imaging : A medical imaging technique used in radiology to form pictures of the anatomy and the physiological processes of the body. Entity1: "FDG-PET/CT", Entity2: "Head and Neck Neoplasms", Relationship: "used for surveillance imaging" 2. Entity1: "Recurrence", Entity2: "Post-treatment period", Relationship: "occurs within" 3. Entity1: "Imaging Modalities", Entity2: "Surveillance", Relationship: "used for" Causalities:- The majority of recurrences after treatment of head and neck cancer occur in the first 2 years . Surveillance can be challenging because of altered anatomy and/or fibrosis from surgery, radiation, and/or chemotherapy . There are no consensus guidelines on the frequency and modality of routine post-treatment imaging in the asymptomatic patient . Practice varies widely across institutions . US, CT, MRI, and PET/CT all have unique advantages and disadvantages when used as surveillance imaging . There is evidence that FDG-PET/CT may be the most sensitive of these modalities . A 12-month PET has been shown to reveal recurrent or second primary cancers in approximately 10% of treated patients ; a 24-month FDG-PET/CT imaging revealed these findings in approximately 5% of treated cases . Most cases of asymptomatic FDG-PET/CT lesion localization occur at distant sites . Whether earlier detection leads to improved disease-specific survival is not established . Standardized multi-institutional imaging-based trials are needed to clearly elucidate the value of routine imaging in the clinically asymptomatic patient . There may be little proven benefit in further imaging if the initial 3-month FDG-PET/CT scan was negative . Ho et al reported no significant difference in 3-year disease-free survival in patients undergoing imaging surveillance versus those only receiving clinical surveillance (41% vs. 46%, P = .91) in this setting . If an FDG-PET/CT at 3 months post-treatment is negative , there are no data to support substantial benefit for further routine imaging in an asymptomatic patient with negative exam . In the absence of multi-institutional prospective data, a tailored approach to surveillance with attention to tumor type, stage, prognostic factors, symptomatology, and physical exam changes or restrictions is appropriate . US of the neck is a well-established tool for nodal surveillance . US is generally widely available, safe, fast, inexpensive, and an accurate modality for examination of the neck for any suspicious nodal disease . Additional post-treatment imaging is indicated for worrisome or equivocal signs/symptoms . Routine annual imaging (repeat use of pretreatment imaging modality) may be indicated to visualize areas inaccessible to routine clinical examination (deep-seated anatomic locations or areas obscured by extensive treatment change) . Tomography, X-Ray Computed : A diagnostic imaging procedure that uses a combination of X-rays and computer technology to produce cross-sectional images of the body. Positron-Emission Tomography : A nuclear medicine functional imaging technique used to observe metabolic processes in the body. Head And Neck Neoplasms : Cancers that occur in the head or neck region, including the nasal cavity, sinuses, lips, mouth, salivary glands, throat, and larynx. Lymphatic Metastasis : The spread of cancer cells through the lymphatic system to distant lymph nodes. Squamous Cell Carcinoma Of Head And Neck : A type of cancer that arises from the squamous cells lining the head and neck region. Cranial Nerves : The twelve pairs of nerves that arise directly from the brain and pass through various foramina in the skull. Skull Base : The area of the skull where the brain rests, including the bones and foramina at the base of the skull. Bone Marrow : The soft, spongy tissue found in the center of bones, responsible for producing blood cells. Cortical Bone : The dense outer surface of bone that forms a protective layer around the internal cavity. Periosteum : A dense layer of vascular connective tissue enveloping the bones except at the surfaces of the joints. Metastasis : The spread of cancer cells from the place where they first formed to another part of the body. Dental Radiography : The use of X-rays to view the teeth and surrounding structures. Relationships:- 1. Entity1: "Magnetic Resonance Imaging", Entity2: "Cranial Nerves", Relationship: "preferred for evaluation" 2. Entity1: "Positron-Emission Tomography", Entity2: "Lymphatic Metastasis", Relationship: "superior for detection" 4. Entity1: "Magnetic Resonance Imaging", Entity2: "Bone Marrow", Relationship: "used for evaluation" 5. Entity1: "Dental Radiography", Entity2: "Dentition", Relationship: "used for evaluation" Causalities:- Appropriate selection and utilization of imaging studies is crucial for proper care of patients with head and neck cancers . Initial imaging of the primary site is performed with CT and/or MRI . in patients with symptoms involving the cranial nerves or tumors encroaching on the skull base MRI is generally preferred over CT . for evaluation of bony erosion or cartilage invasion that may occur with some head and neck tumors (e.g., laryngeal cancer) CT is complementary to MRI . in patients with head and neck cancers involving the bone MRI is needed to evaluate the extent of bone marrow invasion . in patients with head and neck cancers involving the bone CT is preferred to evaluate cortical bone erosion or periosteal invasion . for cancers originating in the base of the tongue MRI can often delineate the boundary between gross tumor and normal muscle more effectively than CT . for differentiating tumor extent from obstructed sinuses or secretions and to evaluate intracranial/dural involvement MRI is also preferable to CT . depending on the primary site Evaluation of lymph node metastases can be done with either CT or MRI . There is evidence to support the superiority of FDG-PET/CT for detecting locoregional nodal and distant metastases in patients with head and neck cancers . in patients with clinically node-negative SCCHN the positive predictive value (PPV) and negative predictive value (NPV) of FDG-PET/CT for detection of cervical lymph node involvement was 0.62 (95% CI, 0.55–0.69) and 0.83 (95% CI, 0.79–0.86), respectively . in patients with cN0 disease 125/144 (87%) negative PET scans were pathologically negative at neck dissection . Findings from PET/CT changed the surgical plan in 22% of patients . for detection of cervical lymph node metastases by FDG-PET/CT a prospective single-center study from Germany (N = 150) showed an NPV of 93.3% (95% CI, 88.2%–98.5%) . if there is concern about metastasis to a specific anatomic area directed CT or MRI may also be performed . Head and neck cancers rarely metastasize to the brain by a hematogenous route ordering a full brain study as part of the initial imaging workup is not routine . for patients who are dentulous and expected to receive postoperative RT a panoramic dental x-ray should be completed before treatment as part of the dental evaluation . if a marginal resection is being considered Panorex is also helpful for evaluation of dentition and mandibular height . Three validated and accepted measures for head and neck cancer-specific issues are: 1. The University of Washington Quality of Life Questionnaire (UW-QOL) 2. The European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire Head and Neck Module (EORTC-QLQ-H&N35) 3. The Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy Head and Neck (FACT-H&N) scale - The Performance Status Scale is a clinician-rated performance scale widely used for patients with head and neck cancers. - The Oral Mucositis Weekly Questionnaire HN (OMWQ-HN) is a validated patient-reported instrument that measures the symptoms of oral mucositis, including mouth and throat pain, and its impact on well-being and function. Use of the Patient-Reported Outcomes version of the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events is encouraged to facilitate evaluation of symptomatic toxicity in patients enrolled in cancer clinical trials . This group is highlighted as those who are most capable of handling intensive treatments and may benefit significantly from combination therapies . - **For PS 2 Patients:** The recommended approach varies slightly, with a continued emphasis on systemic therapies, palliative radiation therapy, or best supportive care . This indicates a level of compromise in treatment options, suggesting that while aggressive treatment is still possible, the focus might shift more towards quality of life . - **For PS 3 Patients:** The treatment options further narrow, still recommending systemic therapy or supportive care but highlighting palliative approaches, reflecting a recognition of the more advanced disease and potentially limited treatment efficacy .\\n\\nSection Name: Principles of Treatment\\n====================\\nEntities:-\\nAntineoplastic Combined Chemotherapy Protocols : Protocols for the administration of more than one antineoplastic agent in combination to treat malignant neoplasms.\\nRadiotherapy : The use of radiation, usually X-rays or gamma rays, to treat disease, especially cancer.\\nSurgical Procedures, Operative : Operations carried out for the correction of deformities and defects, repair of injuries, and diagnosis and cure of certain diseases.\\nSystemic Therapy : A treatment using substances that travel through the bloodstream, reaching and affecting cells all over the body.\\nRadiation Therapy : The use of high-energy radiation from x-rays, gamma rays, neutrons, protons, and other sources to kill cancer cells and shrink tumors.\\nSurgical Procedure : A procedure involving an incision with instruments; performed to repair damage or arrest disease in a living body.\\nChemotherapy : A type of cancer treatment that uses one or more anti-cancer drugs as part of a standardized chemotherapy regimen.\\nSurgery : A medical specialty that uses operative manual and instrumental techniques on a patient to investigate or treat a pathological condition such as disease or injury.\\n\\nRelationships:-\\n1. Entity1: \"Docetaxel\", Entity2: \"Chemoradiotherapy\", Relationship: \"alternative treatment\"\\n\\nCausalities:-\\n In patients with a PS of 0 or 1 , the recommended treatment of newly diagnosed, very advanced disease is concurrent systemic therapy/RT, with a large amount of phase III data supporting high-dose cisplatin as a category 1 preferred recommendation .\\n\\n There are also considerable phase III data from Europe that support the use of carboplatin/5-FU with concurrent RT . This treatment is also considered a category 1 preferred option .\\n\\n Cisplatin-based induction systemic therapy has been studied, followed by RT alone or chemoradiation with a weekly platinum or cetuximab . However, an improvement in OS with the incorporation of induction chemotherapy, compared to proceeding directly to state-of-the-art concurrent systemic therapy/RT, has not been established in randomized studies .\\n\\n Cetuximab with concurrent RT is a category 2B option based on phase II and phase III data but is distinctly inferior to cisplatin with concurrent RT , particularly in patients with HPV-positive disease .\\n\\n Other chemoradiation options include carboplatin/paclitaxel (category 2B based on less panel consensus), weekly cisplatin 40 mg/m\u00b2, and docetaxel (for patients not eligible for cisplatin) . Category 2B chemoradiation options that the panel has deemed useful only in select circumstances are 5-FU/hydroxyurea, cisplatin with infusional 5-FU, and cisplatin/paclitaxel.\\n\\n Other options for patients with a PS of 2\u20133 are described in the algorithm.\\n\\nSection Name: Metastatic Disease\\n====================\\nEntities:-\\nNeoplasm Metastasis : The transfer of a neoplasm from one organ or part of the body to another remote from the primary site.\\nMetastatic Malignant Neoplasm : A malignant neoplasm that has spread from its original site to a different location.\\nMetastasis : The spread of a cancer or other disease from one organ or part to another not directly connected with it.\\nPalliative Care : An interdisciplinary medical caregiving approach aimed at optimizing quality of life and mitigating suffering among people with serious, complex illness.\\nRadiotherapy : A treatment that uses high doses of radiation to kill cancer cells and shrink tumors.\\nRadiation Therapy : The use of ionizing radiation, generally as part of cancer treatment to control or kill malignant cells.\\nSurgical Procedures, Operative : Operations carried out for the correction of deformities and defects, repair of injuries, and diagnosis and cure of certain diseases.\\nSurgical Procedure : A medical procedure involving an incision with instruments; prompt: edge - The edge which needs to be verified. explanation - Explanation of what the edge represents and its validity. causal_direction - Either Positive or Negative or Unknown. A positive influence direction indicates that both factors change in the same direction (e.g. an increase causes an increase effect). A negative influence direction indicates the opposite changes (e.g. an increase causes a decrease effect). causal_factor - Is necessary or sufficient condition for an effect to occur. Exposure is a term commonly used in epidemiology to denote any condition that is considered as a possible cause of disease. Exposure is considered necessary when it always precedes the effects (e.g. symptoms) and always presents when the effects occur. A sufficient cause is a causal factor whose presence or occurrence guarantees the occurrence of symptom. causal_distance - Either Distal or Proximal or Unknown. The distal factors lie towards the beginning of causal chain (i.e. indirect causal factors). The the proximal factors lie towards the end of the chain (i.e. cause directly or almost directly the effect). Causality Tags: for action, for cause, for condition and for effect. Cause (C): The reason or origin that leads to an effect. Causes often involve disease conditions, risk factors, or underlying mechanisms. Effect (E): The outcome or result of a cause. Effects usually represent clinical outcomes, complications, or results of a specific cause. Condition (CO): The circumstance or prerequisite required for an action or effect to occur. Conditions may include patient characteristics, clinical scenarios, or specific diagnostic criteria. Action (A): The recommended or described response or activity to address a cause or condition.
